bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Helen Wheeler, November 10, 1941

div1.p: Hench returns the rest of Kelly's and Peabody's research material to the Welch Medical Library. He questions Wheeler about incomplete and missing items from the collections.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Helen Wheeler, November 10, 1941
div1.opener:
November 10, 1941
Miss Helen Wheeler
Welch Medical Library
1900 East Monument Street
Baltimore, Maryland
My dear Miss Wheeler:
div1.p:
You have been very patient with me and I am returning herewith the
remains of the Kelly and Peabody data on yellow fever which you loaned me
some time ago. I have copied much of it (photostats, etc.).

When I returned the bulk of the material to you some weeks ago did
I call your attention to a few incomplete items in your Peabody collection?

list.item:
1. Your file of correspondence between Moran and Peabody is incomplete.
For example, Peabody's letter of Oct. 15, 1928 to Moran speaks of one Peabody had
previously received from Moran and Moran's letter to Peabody July 7, 1929 speaks
of one Moran had written on Oct. 29, 1928. Neither of these letters of Moran is
in your material. Perhaps Peabody never gave them to you. However, I have
written him about this and he thinks he did.

2. Parts of at least two letters are missing, for example, Peabody's
letter to Col. Kean Nov. 13, 1928, page 2 is missing.

3. Your Peabody collection includes unidentified newspaper clippings
on the deaths of Agramonte and Folk. They seem to have been clipped from “The
Sun” but I can't tell what city--Baltimore Sun or New York Sun. Dr. Peabody sus-
pected they were from the Baltimore Sun but wasn't sure. Do you know which paper?

4. I still haven't been able to find the excellent photographs of Camp
Lazear used in Dr. Kelly's book “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”. Dr. Kelly told
me in May he was sure he'd given you practically everything. His secretary has
since searched his library in vain for them and believes you must have them some-
where. I do hate to bother you about this but could they have been displaced from
the main part of your Kelly collection and been put in some photographic file?
I would appreciate greatly knowing about this.

div1.p:
I am sending you two reprints of a recent article of mine on the yellow
fever story. I thought Dr. Segerist might like to read a copy and you might care
to file one with your yellow fever data.

If you uncover any additional yellow fever material I would appreciate it
greatly if you would let me know.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
